name: Western Swamphen
description: It has dark blue feathers, often with a reddish tinge, with the back and wings transitioning to greenish-blue or black. It features a red beak and frontal shield, orange legs, and striking white feathers under the tail.
spread_note: Tropical and subtropical zones of Europe, Asia, Africa, and Australia
image_alt: Western Swamphen, photo: Tereza Mrhálková, Prague Zoo
proportions: Length 38–50 cm; wingspan 70–100 cm; weight 0.5–1.3 kg
attractions: Swamphens are related to moorhens and rails, within the order Gruiformes. Their relatively short necks and hunched posture suggest they often push through dense vegetation. The western swamphen nests in overgrown water bodies but forages in reeds or tall grass too. Sometimes it forms temporary groups of unrelated birds (mostly males), though family flocks with a few adults and their offspring are more common. Only one or two dominant females nest, laying eggs in a shared nest, and all group members care for the young.
breeding: We’ve kept them since 2005 and have bred them since 2012.
